settings.specialized__what_title: How Can Hairstyling Result in Hair Thinning or Hair Loss?
settings.specialized__what_content: Hairstyles that result in constant pulling on the scalp, or specific areas of the scalp, can result in hair loss. If the hairstyle puts too much pressure on the hair then you may notice hair breakage rather than hair loss.

settings.heading: Which hairstyles can cause hair loss, thinning, or breakage?
settings.specialized__faqs_ans: Any hairstyle that pulls on your hair and/or scalp can cause hair loss, thinning, and breakage. In particular, very tight ponytails, buns, braids, cornrows, dreadlocks, extensions, and weaves can often cause hair damage if they are applied too tightly.

settings.heading: Signs Of Traction Alopecia Hair Damage:
settings.specialized__faqs_ans:
• Sore scalp
  • Headaches
  • Loosened hairs
  • Split ends
  • Hair breakage
  • An increased amount of hair shedding when brushing or washing hair
  • Small bald spots where ponytail, bun, or other restrictive hairstyle sits

settings.heading: Is Traction Alopecia Hair Loss and Hair Damage Permanent?
settings.specialized__faqs_ans:
Most hair damage from hair styling is not permanent, however, hair damage that results in follicle damage can be permanent. Hair thinning that occurs from hairstyles that rub on the hair and result in hair damage or hair loss is typically known as Traction Alopecia.

While most cases of Traction Alopecia are resolved once an individual stops styling their hair in a restrictive way, some can cause permanent follicle damage. Unfortunately, once hair follicles become damaged they cannot grow hair, or the hair that does grow from those follicles may be negatively affected and become thinner than previously.

Hair breakage is a common issue that occurs from hair styling or hair treatments, and this issue is not one that is permanent. Hair breakage happens when the hair strands become weak at a certain point on the hair shaft and break off under stress. Stopping the use of damaging hair styles and supporting your hair's health and strength will allow your hair to recover and grow back.

If you begin to notice your hair is breaking, or that you are noticing thinning or bald spots, you should stop styling your hair in any restrictive styles immediately to limit the amount of damage.

settings.heading: How to Support Hair Recovery After Hair Styling Damage:
settings.specialized__faqs_ans:
Hair loss, thinning, and breakage caused by hair styling are oftentimes temporary and hair health can be recovered using more protective hair styling methods and by implementing a few best practices to best support your hair health and growth.

Best hair care practices:

  • Use gentle hair care and avoid harsh ingredients such as parabens, phthalates, sulfates, and artificial fragrances.
  • Support your hair health and growth with Tru Bloom Vitamins. Our Tru Bloom Hair Vitamins have received thousands of positive reviews from real customers, many of whom have shared their hair and health journeys with us. Visit our 60-Day Challenge to see thousands of reviews and before/after photos.
  • Swap your cotton pillowcase for a satin one instead. Cotton can pull at your hair as you sleep, causing more breakage and damage to your hair. A satin pillowcase will allow your hair to move more freely and without damage. Side note: Satin pillowcases, unlike silk pillowcases, are a great vegan option.
  • Apply scalp treatments weekly. The Beach Goddess Hot Oil Hair Mask is a natural hair treatment to help deeply nourish your scalp and hair to support your best hair growth. This incredible Hot Oil Hair Mask contains proven Hair Superfoods, which can fully penetrate the human hair shaft - to repair & revitalize hair from the inside-out.
  • Reduce heat styling practices. Instead of using heat tools on your hair try to embrace your natural hair texture or use heatless hair styling methods. Heat tools can cause damage to your hair and may result in hair breakage.
